headline.main: Data on Deaths From Obesity Is Inflated, U.S. Agency Says

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that its widely publicized estimate that 400,000 Americans die each year from being too fat is wrong and that it will submit new, lower figure to Journal of American Medical Assn; says it will be simple correction of inadvertent calculation error; but that figure has taken on life of its own; those concerned about obesity cite it to show that being fat is almost as bad as smoking; Dr Stanton A Glantz, professor of medicine and director of Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education at University of California, San Francisco, estimates that number of deaths from obesity to be more like 100,000 than 400,000 (M)

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: CENTER FOR TOBACCO CONTROL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that its widely publicized estimate that 400,000 Americans die each year from being too fat is wrong and that it will submit a new, lower figure to the medical journal that published its original estimate last March. It will be a simple correction of an inadvertent calculation error, the centers said.
docs.snippet: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that its estimate that 400,000 Americans die each year from obesity was too high because of a calculation error.
